title: 4 in 10 Malaysians say no difference between SST and GST: survey
text:
Most of the survey respondents were also unaware of Malaysia’s sugar tax and upcoming digital service tax. Pixabay

46% of Malaysians see no difference between SST and GST, a Vase.ai survey has found.

The survey polled 1,045 Malaysians, the majority of which earn RM3,000 or less per month.

30% of respondents said SST was more expensive than GST, while 13% said it was cheaper.

70% wanted Budget 2020 to impose price controls on basic necessities like food.

Never mind the debate over GST and SST: nearly half of all Malaysians feel there is no difference between the two, a recent survey by Vase.ai has found.

Read also: Mahathir now says ‘no reason’ to revive GST ‘which was rejected by the people’

The survey, published on Monday (Oct 7), polled a nationally representative sample of 1,045 Malaysians, the majority of which earned RM3,000 (US$716) or less per month.

Most of the respondents were millennials in the 18 to 34 age bracket. Over 60 per cent of respondents were Malay. Vase.ai

Most of the respondents were full time white collar workers in the private sector. Sixty per cent held degrees. Vase.ai

The majority of respondents earned RM3,000 and below, while the next biggest group were respondents with no fixed monthly income. Vase.ai

When asked about the difference between SST and GST, 46 per cent of respondents said there was no difference between the two.

Vase.ai

Thirty per cent said SST was more expensive than GST, while 13 per cent said it was cheaper.

About one in three respondents wanted GST to be reinstated with a lower tax rate of 3 per cent.

The survey also asked respondents about Malaysia’s sugar tax and the upcoming digital service tax, which is a 6 per cent tax on consumers buying online services like Spotify, Netflix, Steam, Lazada, Shopee, and Zalora.

Nearly half the of respondents were not aware Malaysia had implemented a sugar tax since July, while over 60 per cent were not aware a digital service tax would kick in in January.

Read also: Malaysia’s new sugar tax kicks in today – and it affects juice and vegetable-based drinks too

When asked about Budget 2020, 90 per cent of respondents said a key concern was addressing and improving the cost of living. Almost 70 per cent hoped the Budget would control prices of basic necessities, and about half the respondents hoped for Government aid to help lower and middle-income families afford homes.

The top three things Malaysians hoped for in Budget 2020 were price-controlled necessities, government aid around home ownership, and welfare aid for lower and middle income families. Vase.ai

About half of all respondents also said they were unhappy with their current standard of living. The top two factors they listed that could remedy the situation were better education and job opportunities, and lower costs of living.

They also listed good health, quality education and justice as the top three UN Sustainable Development Goals important to Malaysians.
